newsitem.title: USA: US Senate panel clears $21 bln energy, water bill.
newsitem.headline: US Senate panel clears $21 bln energy, water bill.

text.p: A Senate appropriations subcommittee Tuesday cleared a $20.7 billion fiscal 1998 spending bill for energy and water programs and to maintain nuclear weapons, down from the White House's request of $22.6 billion.

Part of the difference between the White House request and the panel's bill was in spending to contract out to the private sector more costs of cleaning contamination from the nuclear weapons program, a subcommittee aide said.

The panel -- which approved the bill quickly and did not provide a breakdown of the spending plan -- approved $300 million to increase outside contracting, down from the White House's $1 billion request, the aide said.
The panel provided more money for nuclear weapons site cleanup and waste management than the White House requested -- $5.318 billion instead of $5.052 billion, he said.

The subcommittee also approved $4.3 billion in spending for nuclear weapons activities including managing the weapons stockpile, up from $3.9 billion for this fiscal year, but down from the White House request of $5.0 billion, the aide said.

For continued work on determining whether the Yucca Mountain site in Nevada will be a suitable long-term storage site for nuclear waste, the panel approved $350 million. The White House requested $380 million.
The panel also approved $301.4 million for programs for solar and renewable energy, up from $266.3 million this fiscal year, but down from the White House request of $344.7 million.
It approved $6 million for next fiscal year for the controversial Animas-La Plata water project in southern Colorado, which was expected to have an overall pricetag of more than $740 million.
Critics say Congress should reject any new money for the project because at least $8 million out of $9 million approved last year has yet to be spent.

The water project has been delayed and criticized because of its hefty cost and environmental impact, and because just one-third of the water diverted in the project was to go to Native American tribes, even though the proposal resulted from a settlement with tribes.
